citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee gives buyers the option of having a puppy neutered before it ships and the licensee says he performs most
of these neuters at his facility without veterinary supervision. The surgeries are done in a multi-use room used for
grooming, surgeries, and other procedures using the licensees own equipment and instruments.
Neutering, as a significant surgery that results in permanent changes to the dogs anatomy and physiology, is considered
a major surgery that should be done by, or under the direct supervision of, a veterinarian.
Dogs neutered at the licensees facility can only be done by, or under the direct supervision of, a veterinarian.
Completion Date: November 6, 2023

Dogs requiring a health certificate for transport are examined by the attending veterinarian, but the licensee fills out and
prints the health certificates, changing the consignor information on some. In at least 4 occasions, the disposition form
said the dogs were being shipped from the licensee to a shelter in Florida, but on the accompanying health certificate, the
shelter was listed as the consignor (the shipper), not the licensee. On those certificates, a completely different name and
address were listed as the consignee (the receiver of the dogs). The licensee confirmed that the dogs are not shipped
from his facility to the shelter’s address on the disposition form, but to the consignee on the health certificate. The
attending veterinarian confirmed that the licensee fills out the health certificates, but was not aware that the licensee was
filling out certificates with people other than the licensee as the consignor.
In order for a health certificate to be valid, the veterinarian signing a health certificate must execute and issue that
certificate, verifying that the information on the certificate is accurate. The ability to track the movement of dogs using
disposition forms and/or health certificates is very important for regulation of the industry and as a tool for tracking the
movement of dogs in disease outbreaks. Incorrect or false information frustrates these efforts and makes disease control
difficult.
Before the licensee turns over a dog for transport in commerce, it must be accompanied by a valid and accurate health
certificate executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian.
To be completed by: November 6, 2023

The licensee uses xylazine and torbugesic when doing neuters, hernia repairs, and dentals at his facility, but there are no
records of their use. The licensee did have a bottle of each of these medications that had labels indicating they were from
his veterinarian, the date dispensed, and the quantity of the medication in the bottle at the time it was dispensed.
Records for medications given to dogs must be kept by the licensee to ensure that they are being used as directed by the
attending veterinarian and in proper amounts that help ensure their efficacy and safety.
The licensee must keep copies of medical records and make the records available for inspection. These include records
of all treatments administered and the dates of administration.
Completion date: November 6, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee gives buyers the option of having a puppy neutered before it ships and the licensee says he performs most 
of these neuters at his facility without veterinary supervision. The surgeries are done in a multi-use room used for 
grooming, surgeries, and other procedures using the licensees own equipment and instruments. 
Neutering, as a significant surgery that results in permanent changes to the dogs anatomy and physiology, is considered 
a major surgery that should be done by, or under the direct supervision of, a veterinarian. 
Dogs neutered at the licensees facility can only be done by, or under the direct supervision of, a veterinarian. 
Completion Date: November 6, 2023 
2.78(a)  Critical
   
Health certification and identification. 
Dogs requiring a health certificate for transport are examined by the attending veterinarian, but the licensee fills out and 
prints the health certificates, changing the consignor information on some. In at least 4 occasions, the disposition form 
said the dogs were being shipped from the licensee to a shelter in Florida, but on the accompanying health certificate, the 
shelter was listed as the consignor (the shipper), not the licensee. On those certificates, a completely different name and 
address were listed as the consignee (the receiver of the dogs). The licensee confirmed that the dogs are not shipped 
from his facility to the shelter’s address on the disposition form, but to the consignee on the health certificate. The 
attending veterinarian confirmed that the licensee fills out the health certificates, but was not aware that the licensee was 
filling out certificates with people other than the licensee as the consignor. 
In order for a health certificate to be valid, the veterinarian signing a health certificate must execute and issue that 
certificate, verifying that the information on the certificate is accurate. The ability to track the movement of dogs using 
disposition forms and/or health certificates is very important for regulation of the industry and as a tool for tracking the 
movement of dogs in disease outbreaks. Incorrect or false information frustrates these efforts and makes disease control 
difficult. 
Before the licensee turns over a dog for transport in commerce, it must be accompanied by a valid and accurate health 
certificate executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian. 
To be completed by: November 6, 2023 
3.13(b)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee uses xylazine and torbugesic when doing neuters, hernia repairs, and dentals at his facility, but there are no 
records of their use. The licensee did have a bottle of each of these medications that had labels indicating they were from 
his veterinarian, the date dispensed, and the quantity of the medication in the bottle at the time it was dispensed. 
Records for medications given to dogs must be kept by the licensee to ensure that they are being used as directed by the 
attending veterinarian and in proper amounts that help ensure their efficacy and safety. 
The licensee must keep copies of medical records and make the records available for inspection. These include records 
of all treatments administered and the dates of administration.  
Completion date: November 6, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
